security_audit.summary: This is a documentation and reference skill containing PowerShell code examples and best practices. All static findings are FALSE POSITIVES - the security scanner misinterpreted markdown documentation containing PowerShell examples as executed code. The skill contains no malicious patterns, only educational content about PowerShell development.

content.value_statement: This skill provides expert guidance for PowerShell development including script templates, best practices for parameters and error handling, Windows Forms and WPF GUI creation patterns, and PowerShell Gallery integration for module management.
actual_capabilities: Creates production-quality PowerShell scripts with proper structure, parameters, and error handling
Develops Windows Forms and WPF GUIs with controls, events, and layout patterns
Searches and manages PowerShell Gallery modules using PSResourceGet
Implements pipeline support and splatting for clean, efficient PowerShell code
Applies Microsoft best practices for naming conventions and code style
limitations: This is a guidance skill and does not execute PowerShell code directly
GUI development examples are Windows-only due to System.Windows.Forms dependency
Requires PowerShell 5.1 or newer for full feature compatibility

use_cases.title: Automate Windows tasks
use_cases.description: Create scripts to automate user management, file operations, and system configuration tasks.

use_cases.title: Build deployment tools
use_cases.description: Develop module-based tools for infrastructure automation and environment configuration.

use_cases.title: Improve script quality
use_cases.description: Apply best practices for error handling, pipeline support, and module design patterns.

prompt_templates.title: Script template
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a PowerShell function named Get-ServerInfo that accepts a ComputerName parameter, connects via CIM, and returns OS version, disk space, and memory info.

prompt_templates.title: GUI development
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a Windows Forms PowerShell script that creates a login dialog with username and password fields, OK and Cancel buttons, and validates inputs before closing.

prompt_templates.title: Module help
prompt_templates.prompt: Find PowerShell modules on the Gallery for Azure resource management. Include module name, version, and install command.

prompt_templates.title: Best practices
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this PowerShell script for best practices: does it use proper naming, error handling, pipeline support, and WhatIf/Confirm parameters?

output_examples.input: Create a function to copy files with progress
output: Use Copy-Item with -Filter and -Recurse for directory copies
Implement Write-Progress for visual feedback during long operations
Add -Force parameter to overwrite existing files
Support WhatIf/Confirm for safe previews of destructive operations
Add Label, TextBox, and Button controls
Return dialog result and user input via script-scoped variables

output_examples.input: Find modules for REST API calls
output: Microsoft.PowerShell.WebRequests.Native HTTP cmdlets built into PowerShell
Invoke-RestMethod and Invoke-WebRequest for API calls
No external module needed for basic REST operations

best_practices: Use Verb-Noun naming with approved verbs from Get-Verb and PascalCase for all identifiers
Implement proper error handling with try/catch blocks and specific exception types
anti_patterns: Avoid using generic noun names like Get-Data or Set-Config without specificity
Do not skip error handling or use -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue without logging
Avoid mixing Write-Host with Write-Output in functions that produce pipeline output

faq.question: What PowerShell version is required?
faq.answer: The skill targets PowerShell 5.1 and newer. Some features like PSResourceGet require PowerShell 7+.

faq.question: Does this run PowerShell code?
faq.answer: No. This skill provides guidance, templates, and best practices. It does not execute or install code.

faq.question: Can I create GUIs for Linux?
faq.answer: Windows Forms and WPF examples require Windows. For cross-platform GUIs, consider web-based approaches.

faq.question: How do I verify module recommendations?
faq.answer: The skill includes a Search-Gallery.ps1 helper script. Always verify modules exist on PowerShell Gallery before installing.

faq.question: What about script execution policy?
faq.answer: The skill does not modify execution policy. Users must run Set-ExecutionPolicy or use -Bypass to run scripts.

faq.question: Can this help with module publishing?
faq.answer: Yes. The references/powershellget.md file covers publishing modules to the PowerShell Gallery.
